title: Question: hypermedia support
body:
Hello there

That's an awesome collection you have here. I just wonder which among all these frameworks come with the most hypermedia support?

title: Ractive.js TodoMVC example app
body:
Hi

This is an example TodoMVC app using [Ractive.js](http://ractivejs.org).

Ractive isn't an MVC framework in the traditional sense, it's a DOM manipulation library. But because it is stateful, template-based, and embraces reactive programming principles, it solves the same problems as MVC frameworks.

Its focus is on ease of use and performance. It works by parsing templates and maintaining a 'parallel DOM' in JavaScript land, which reacts to state changes and updates the DOM whenever necessary.

The app is tested in all modern browsers and meets the specification, as far as I can tell. Let me know if you have any questions about it.

Thanks!

title: Added Durandal framework
body:
There have been a couple of requests for creating a durandal example in here. This [discussion ](https://github.com/tastejs/todomvc/issues/518) was closed a few months back with a note to reopen when there is a spec-compliant implementation. This is the spec compliant implementation.

Another [request for durandal](https://github.com/tastejs/todomvc/issues/634) was made a few weeks back.

As for why include Durandal - EisenbergEffect (also one of the main contributers to durandal) has outlined the framework well in this [comment ](https://github.com/tastejs/todomvc/issues/518#issuecomment-15951713).

I see durandal gathering a fair bit of steam in the past few months, and we're close to production with our durandal based financial services site from our organization. 

As mentioned in the comments, durandal uses a combination of knockout and sammy to provide a high level framework for single page applications.

My code borrows heavily from the knockout js example for all the data binding, but to demonstrate the capabilities of durandal illustrates the following concepts

* Composition - The html is composed from multiple modules - *shell*, *entry* and *list*. The shell contains markup references for *entry* and *list* modules. The *entry* module provides the markup and viewmodel only for entering tasks. The *list* module is responsible for display and managing the list of tasks 

* Communication - The implementation demonstrates durandals eventing system by making the entry module agnostic of the *list* module. the *entry* module simply broadcasts the addition of a new task which is then picked up  by the *list* module.

* Module Lifecycle - the *list* module has an activation event which is triggered by the durandal framework. On activation, the tasks are retrieved from the local storage and initialized in the observable array.

I think I've adhered to all the coding guidelines, but the only issue is that since I didn't want to disturb the learn.json file in the root directory, the page does not show the helper on the left hand side. Let me know what i need to do to make that work.

title: TodoMVC OzJS example
body:
Hi, here is a TodoMVC example using [oz.js](http://ozjs.org/#overview) + [OzJS micro-framework](http://ozjs.org/#framework).

#### The key features  

* Combining multiple independent, single purpose modules to achieve the same effect as All-in-One MVC framework
* Cocoa-like MVC style
* The architecture is based on messaging
* Examples for business view components 
* Examples for jQuery-compatible and non-All-in-One library ([DollarJS](http://ozjs.org/DollarJS/))
* Examples for event-based model wrapper ([NervJS](http://ozjs.org/NervJS/))

title: AngularJS Item Trimming
body:
**DON'T MERGE**

I would like to keep this PR dangling until AngularJS 1.2 is out or `ng-trim` gets backported to the stable AngularJS version line. This fixes the trimming issue described in #635 and includes one fix `ngRepeat` needs to work with 1.1. I don't think it's worth including crazy hacks to make this work with the current stable release.

title: Lavaca
body:
We recreated our example in reference to this pull request https://github.com/tastejs/todomvc/pull/316. I tried attaching this pull request to that issue but couldn't figure out how.

This implementation is a complete rewrite using [Lavaca](http://getlavaca.com) post 2.0. We added some information and helpful links to the readme. thanks

title: Confused about layouts in TodoMVC/backbone_marionette
body: According to [this page](https://github.com/marionettejs/backbone.marionette/wiki/The-relationship-between-regions-and-layouts), the difference between a `Layout` and an `ItemView` in Marionette is that a layout can contain regions into which other layouts or views can be rendered. In [`TodoMVCLayout.js`](https://github.com/tastejs/todomvc/blob/gh-pages/labs/architecture-examples/backbone_marionette/js/TodoMVC.Layout.js), two elements are added to the `Layout` module, but one of these (`Header`) is defined as an `ItemView` not a `Layout`. The other, `Footer`, is defined as a `Layout`, but as far as I can tell does not contain any regions. I found this rather confusing. Is there a value in defining the header and footer as `Layout`s, or would it be reasonable to define them as plain `ItemView`s, and define them in the `TodoList.Views` module?

title: Some nitpicking for unifying the todos
body:
Hi. I'm modeling after the existing todos for my work, and here are some small quirks I've noticed in the existing stable ones:

- Backbone doesn't implement esc on edit. 
- Ember/Dojo's height are a pixel off compared to the rest (with todos present).
- Some todos trim the input on edit, some don't (e.g. Backbone).

title: Ember.js example updates todo on value change
TodoMVC Mozart example
body:
This is an example TodoMVC application written in the Mozart framework (http://mozart.io)

Mozart is a new client side MVC framework, developed by myself (Tom Cully) and the team at Bigcommerce (http://bigcommerce.com). The company has made the framework open source as of 1st July 2013.

title: Angular app requires two back button presses to return to previous site.
body:
To replicate the issue visit the [TodoMVC Angular imlimentation](http://todomvc.com/architecture-examples/angularjs/) (that's the same link that's posted on the [TodoMVC homepage](http://todomvc.com/).) Clicking the back button from the app will then remove the `#/` from the end of the URL instead of returning to the previous site.

That's an unnecessary addition to the browser history, and an interuption in the UX.

title: Adding sumerian.io, a JavaScript SPA Development Suite
body: I am the creator of a new SPA development suite called sumerian.io (http://sumerian.io). I have created a version of the todos application using my framework, and would like to apply it to your project.

title: Realtime: Addition of Sails.JS as a Realtime MVC framework.
body:
I'd like to propose the [Sails.JS](http://www.sailsjs.org) be added to todoMVC as a Realtime MVC framework.  Sails.JS is a newer Node.JS Framework built on proven code like express and socket.IO.   While still being new, Sails.JS packs quite a punch out of the box.  Sails.JS supports websockets via Socket.IO and has a RESTful JSON api that uses the same codebase out of the box.  Blueprints are another feature that makes Sails.JS one of the fastest frameworks to get started with.  With blueprints, all you need is a model, the framework will handle the controller, sockets, and api for you.  This isn't to say that you CAN"T write your own controllers and such, it just makes it easier and faster for you to get a simple API up and running.

When coupled together with front-end frameworks that take advantage of the websockets, Sails.JS can help you build a stunning fast front-end that use a back-end just as fast.

Lets discuss this and see what we think?

title: 1.2 release
body:
We should do another release now that we've converted most of the apps to Bower and have an awesome new sidebar.

- [ ] Write a G+ post about the release and how we use Bower and some other smart stuff.
- [ ] Merge PRs
- [ ] Any open issues we should fix before release?
- [ ] Before release, go through the apps and site and make sure everything works correctly.
- [ ] Update site url on download link, changelog, and tag release.
- [ ] Announce on Twitter/G+ (RT/RP!)
- [ ] Send in to JavaScript Weekly, Hacker News and Reddit.

Feel free to add anything else. We can reuse this one for other releases.

-

We're shooting for a release on thursday, but we should already begin preparing.

-

@sindresorhus @addyosmani @passy @stephenplusplus

title: Ember.js example not equivalent comparison
body: The Ember example appears to be fractionally slower than the Angular and Backbone, but this is because the item is added to the list on key up rather than key down like the others. Is this difference intentional? I believed Ember to be slower than the other frameworks before noticing this and I'd image I'm not the only one.

title: Comments/code side-by-side view
body:
We've been thinking about how we could make it easier for users to quickly go through an app and understand it. One is better code comments #385.

Another is http://www.explainjs.com which does something interesting by extracting the code comments and showing them besides the code Docco style. We should think about doing something like this ourselves. Though we would need some kind of simple file browsers since an app contains multiple files. I would also like syntax highlighting. We could use the explainjs API or host something ourselves.

Let us know if anyone is interested in prototyping something like this.

Thoughts?

title: TodoMVC using Mojito (v0.5.6 - with updates)
body:
Originally for #435 - couldn't find a way to update the same pull request - may be because I scratched the original fork rather than rebasing again.


### Commit log

The files in the folder comprise of only the code and not the final running application.

After all hits-and-tries realized that I cannot make it up and running on Github because the application needs to make calls to `POST /tunnel` and Github pages won't allow that.

title: Select apps that will move to TasteLang
body:
As part of our evolution to TasteJS, we're going to migrate compile to JS apps over to TasteLang, a sub-project which will allow us to scale up inclusion of those types of apps without having to say no so often to combo apps (e.g Angular + CoffeeScript).

This issue is to track which apps we want to move. Please feel free to list your selections :)

title: Rewrite of ExtJS using best practices
body:
Hi Pascal,

It turns out the easiest way of doing this was to re-fork, create my own branch (thus isolating it from everyone else's commits), redo my changes (not a big deal) and then
do the rebase, and push gh-pages

I hope this is correct. Please let me know and thanks again for your help!

Kevin
